Such a TathÄgata transformation lotus flower suddenly in an instant becomes an unpleasant form, foul-smelling and disgusting, causing one to not enjoy it. In this way, within the flower appears a Buddha form, sitting cross-legged, emitting hundreds of thousands of lights, with excellent characteristics and dignified features, pleasing to the eyes of people.
Having known this, many gods, dragons, yakshas, gandharvas, asuras, mahoragas, humans, and non-humans made offerings and paid homage.
It is so, it is so!
Good sons!
The Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, with the wisdom and light of the Buddha, sees with his eyes the desires, anger, ignorance, greed, and afflictions of all beings.
Those good men and good women, who are overwhelmed by afflictions, have koá¹­is of buddhas in their wombs, all like me.

The Tathagata's wisdom eye observes that they have the essence of the Buddha-Dharma, sitting in meditation posture, still and unmoving, amidst all the defiled afflictions. The Tathagata's treasury of the Dharma is originally unshakable, and cannot be tainted by the views of the various realms of existence.
Therefore, I now say this:
All those tathÄgatas are no different from me.
Good sons!
In this way, the TathÄgata uses the eye of Buddha-knowledge to see the tathÄgatagarbha in all sentient beings.
Good sons!

It is like using the divine eye to see such evil forms and foul smells, wrapped and oppressed by the petals of various lotus flowers. Therefore, with the divine eye, one sees the true body of the Buddha sitting in full lotus posture within those flowers.
Having known this, if one wishes to see the TathÄgata, one must remove the foul and evil karma in order to reveal the form of the Buddha.
It is just like this!
Good sons!

The TathÄgata observes all sentient beings with the eye of Buddha, in order to eliminate the sheaths of desire, anger, ignorance, greed, and the afflictions of ignorance in those sentient beings, and thus teaches the Dharma for them;

Good sons!
Whether the TathÄgata appears in the world or not, the nature of dharmas, the dharma realm, and the tathÄgatagarbha of all sentient beings are eternally unchanging.
Moreover, good sons!

If there are sentient beings who are disgusted with the afflictions that bind them, in order to eliminate the afflictions that bind them and purify the wisdom of the TathÄgata, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One teaches the essential Dharma to the bodhisattvas, doing such things to cause their superior understanding.
Having already had superior understanding, they uphold the Dharma with perseverance, and then attain liberation from all afflictions and secondary afflictions.
At that time, the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One is counted in the world, and is able to perform the Buddha's work of the TathÄgata.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:

It is like a honey hive hanging from a large tree, round in shape, guarded by hundreds of thousands of bees, protecting the honey. A man seeking honey, with skillful means, drives away the bees and takes the honey, using it as he wishes.
It is just like this!
Good man!

All sentient beings are like a honey hive, guarded and protected by many hundreds of thousands of afflictions and secondary afflictions. The Buddha's wisdom and insight can know this and then attain perfect enlightenment.
Good man!
In this way, the wise man, knowing the honey, also understands that it is guarded by many hundreds of thousands of troublesome bees;
In this way, all sentient beings, known by the TathÄgata's wisdom and insight, have already become Buddhas, but are obstructed by many hundreds of thousands of afflictions and secondary afflictions.
Good man!

The TathÄgata, with the power of skillful means, for the sake of those who harm bees, teaches all sentient beings to chase away desire, anger, ignorance, arrogance, conceit, concealment, rage, hatred, jealousy, and stinginess, and the afflictions and secondary afflictions. In this way, he teaches the Dharma to enable sentient beings to be unstained by afflictions, to be without oppression and affliction, and to not associate with them.
Good man!
How do I, with the TathÄgata's wisdom and vision, purify and perform Buddha-works in the world for these sentient beings?
Good man!
With pure eyes, I see that sentient beings are thus pure.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Just like a honey hive, round in shape, guarded by bees and concealed,

I see sentient beings in the three existences, also no different from a honey hive,

Always in the world like a honey vessel, like eloquence speaking of good honey, causing one to realize the TathÄgata's pure Dharma body.
Moreover, good man!
It is like rice, wheat, millet, and beans, whose essential grains are wrapped in husks, if the husks are not removed they are unfit for consumption.
Good man!
People seeking food, whether male or female, use a pestle and mortar to pound and remove the husks to fill their bellies.
Thus, thus!
Good man!

The TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, with the eye of the TathÄgata, sees that all sentient beings are endowed with the essence of the TathÄgata, wrapped in the sheath of afflictions. That TathÄgata-store dwells within all afflictions. The TathÄgata removes the sheath of afflictions for those sentient beings, purifies them, and causes them to become Buddhas. He expounds the Dharma for them, always thinking:

It is like a foul-smelling heap of filth, and there is a man who suddenly drops a gold brick beside it, which then falls into the filth;

But this gold treasure sinks in the foul stench, perhaps for ten years, perhaps twenty years, perhaps fifty years, perhaps a hundred thousand years, dwelling in the filth, but its original substance is not destroyed, not tainted, and also cannot benefit people.

Those with the heavenly eye see the gold brick in the foul stench and tell others:

The heap of foul stench is called the various afflictions and secondary afflictions;

Those with the heavenly eye are the Tathagata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One.

The true superior treasure of the Tathagata's Dharma-nature of all sentient beings is submerged in the foul stench of afflictions. One with the heavenly eye observes and sees, and tells other people:
'Here there is gold, you should take it, wash it, and use it as you wish.
Submerged in the filth of afflictions flowing for a long night, knowing those afflictions to be guest-dust,

It is like a poor man, in the ground of his house there is a great treasure trove, one yojana long and wide, filled with gold;

All sentient beings dwell in the house of grasping and conceptualization, yet they have the treasure of the Buddha's wisdom, powers, and fearlessness. In form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, they are addicted and suffer;

The TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, is the Dharma treasury of the world. The TathÄgata, with his pure eye, sees that all sentient beings are endowed with the TathÄgata-store, and therefore expounds the wonderful Dharma for the bodhisattvas.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:

Seeing this, I teach the bodhisattvas:
You should dig out this great treasure of wisdom, attain freedom from poverty and become a World-Honored One, able to bestow the unsurpassed Dharma wealth.

The TathÄgata, with the eye of the TathÄgata, sees that within the desires, hatred, ignorance, greed, and afflictions of all sentient beings, down to the very skin, there is the nature of the TathÄgata-garbha. Because of this, they are called those with the nature.

If they see the TathÄgata, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, it causes all Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas to understand the wisdom of the TathÄgata and causes it to be revealed.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½Just as a tree is found within a fig seed,
and the fig sprouts can all be obtained,

The Buddha's eye of the most supreme and pure observes that within them is the essence of the TathÄgata.
This storehouse that is not destroyed is called sentient beings, within which is wisdom that is no different,
Abiding peacefully in concentration, dwelling in tranquility, also unmoving, without attainment.
For their sake, I expound the Dharma, how can they attain perfect enlightenment?
Just like a seed becoming a great tree, it will be the support for the world.
Moreover, good man!
It is like a poor person who uses all kinds of jewels to make an image of the TathÄgata, one cubit in length.

This poor man, wanting to carry the jeweled image through dangerous paths, fearing it will be stolen, takes some foul-smelling, broken, and worn-out cloth to wrap around the image, so that people will not notice it.

This poor man suddenly died in the wilderness, and the precious image of the TathÄgata, wrapped in foul and filthy rags, was discarded on the ground, rolling in the wilderness;
People passing by would step on it, jump over it, not knowing that there was a TathÄgata image inside.
Because it was wrapped in foul and filthy rags, discarded on the ground, they all despised it, how could they think of it as a Buddha?
At that time, the gods dwelling in the wilderness saw it with their heavenly eyes and immediately told the other travelers:
'You people!
There is an image of the TathÄgata in these filthy rags, you should quickly unwrap it, all the worlds should pay homage to it.'
It is just like this!
Good man!

The TathÄgata, with the eye of a TathÄgata, sees that all sentient beings are like that foul-smelling and filthy cloth, long wandering in the dangerous paths and wilderness of birth and death, and receiving immeasurable animal bodies.
In the midst of the foul-smelling and filthy cloth of the afflictions of all sentient beings, there is the TathÄgata's essence, no different from me;
The TathÄgata, in order to untie the binding of the filthy cloth of afflictions, expounds the wonderful Dharma for the bodhisattvas:
How can one attain the pure TathÄgata's wisdom and vision, leave behind the afflictions, and obtain the worship of all worlds, just as I have?
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
Like a filthy cloth that is disgusting, it wraps the TathÄgata's essence;
The jeweled image is wrapped in a filthy cloth, abandoned in the dangerous and evil wilderness.
The gods, with their heavenly eyes, having seen this, immediately tell the travelers and others, saying:
You should quickly unwrap it and pay homage.'
With my heavenly eye, I see thus, and observe all sentient beings,
Wrapped in the cloth of afflictions, greatly suffering the pains of birth and death.
I see in the filthy cloth of afflictions, the body of the TathÄgata sitting in full lotus posture,
Abiding in stillness, unmoving, all without existence, liberated.
Having seen this, I am startled and awakened. Listen attentively, abide in supreme enlightenment,
All sentient beings are thus. In the midst of fear, there is always a Buddha.
Having unwrapped it, the Buddha's body appears. At that time, all afflictions are still.
Therefore, he is called the TathÄgata. Devas and humans rejoice and make offerings.'
Moreover, good man!

There may be a lonely woman, with an ugly and foul appearance, as repulsive as a ghost, living in a poor and evil house, who accidentally becomes pregnant, and that fetus is definitely destined to become a wheel-turning king;
yet that woman, even though pregnant, has never had such thoughts, only harboring a poor and lowly mind. Due to her weak mind, she always thinks like this:
My appearance is ugly, and I spend my days in a poor and evil house. I don't even know what kind of person is born in my womb.
It is just like this, just like this!
Good man!
All sentient beings have no master and no refuge. Born in the three realms of existence, they rely on a poor and evil house, oppressed by the suffering of birth and death.
Yet each and every sentient being has the TathÄgata-nature and is endowed with the TathÄgata-store. Those sentient beings are unaware and do not know this.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

The TathÄgata does not allow all sentient beings to deceive themselves. The Buddha teaches the Dharma:

The Dharma treasury in their bodies like a womb.ğŸ”½Having seen this, I told the Bodhisattva,

Before long, one's own body will become a Buddha,ğŸ”½Before long, one will sit at the site of enlightenment,

It is like making a mold with wax, or making a horse-shaped, elephant-shaped, male-shaped, or female-shaped mold, covering it with mud, and using fire to heat it. Molten true gold is poured into the mold, and after it cools, this craftsman takes it back to his house;

The outside of the mold is covered with black mud, the shape is scorched and ugly, but inside there is a golden image. Either the craftsman or the craftsman's disciple, knowing that the mold is cold, immediately breaks the mud. After it is cleaned, in an instant, this golden treasure image becomes pure.
It is like this, like this!

The TathÄgata sees all sentient beings with the TathÄgata's eye as if they were golden images in molds, externally covered by the mud of afflictions, but internally full of the Buddha's Dharma and the treasure of uncontaminated wisdom.

I now observe and see that all sentient beings are like this, in the assembly of bodhisattvas expounding the wonderful Dharma. If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain tranquility and coolness, the TathÄgata, for those sentient beings, with the adamantine weapon purifies their Dharma eye, removes their afflictions and secondary afflictions, and in order to purify the TathÄgata's treasury of wisdom.
Good man!
